title: Literature: Dance
text: The dataset used in this analysis was harvested from the Web of Science, includes all 611 publications returned for the query dance AND (archaeology OR archeology OR anthropology), and uses the bibliometrix package for analysis.

title: Literature: Dance
text:
Conceptual structure

Co-word analysis
The co-word analysis maps the conceptual structure of a research domain using the co-occurrence of author keywords in the bibliographic collection.

Author’s keywords

# using authors keywords
cw <- conceptualStructure(df,
                          field = "DE",
                          method = "MCA",
                          minDegree = 5,
                          clust = "auto",
                          stemming = FALSE,
                          labelsize = 8)















Publisher’s keywords

# using publishers keywords
cw <- conceptualStructure(df,
                          field = "ID",
                          method = "MCA",
                          minDegree = 5,
                          clust = "auto",
                          stemming = FALSE,
                          labelsize = 8)

title: Literature: Dance
text:
Thematic mapping
From (Cobo et al. 2011, 150–51):

Themes in the upper-right quadrant are both well developed and important for the structuring ofa research field. They are known as the motor-themes of the specialty, given that they present strong centrality and high density. The placement of themes in this quadrant implies that they are related externally to concepts applicable to other themes that are conceptually closely related.
Themes in the upper-left quadrant have well developed internal ties but unimportant external ties and so are of only marginal importance for the field. These themes are very specialized and peripheral in character.
Themes in the lower-left quadrant are both weakly developed and marginal. The themes of this quadrant have low density and low centrality, mainly representing either emerging or disappearing themes.
Themes in the lower-right quadrant are important for a research field but are not developed. So, this quadrant groups transversal and general, basic themes.


Authors’ keywords

# keyword map
map1 = thematicMap(df,
                   field = "DE",
                   n = 1000,
                   minfreq = 4,
                   ngrams = 1,
                   stemming = FALSE,
                   size = 0.3,
                   n.labels = 1,
                   community.repulsion = 0.1,
                   cluster = "walktrap",
                   repel = TRUE)
# plot map
plot(map1$map)






Publisher’s keywords

# keyword map
map2 = thematicMap(df,
                   field = "ID",
                   n = 1000,
                   minfreq = 4,
                   ngrams = 1,
                   stemming = FALSE,
                   size = 0.6,
                   n.labels = 1,
                   community.repulsion = 0.1,
                   cluster = "walktrap",
                   repel = TRUE)
# plot map
plot(map2$map)

title: Literature: Dance
text:
Social structure

Author collaboration
Scientific collaborations are plotted where nodes are authors and links are co-authorships, illustrating collaborations between authors.

# author collaboration network
auth.collab <- biblioNetwork(df,
                             analysis = "collaboration",
                             network = "authors",
                             sep = ";")

# network plot
auth.collabnet = networkPlot(auth.collab,
                             n = 75,
                             Title = "Author Collaboration",
                             type = "mds",
                             halo = TRUE,
                             weighted = TRUE,
                             size = 5,
                             edgesize = 1,
                             labelsize = 0.5,
                             remove.isolates = TRUE)






Edu collaboration
Scientific collaborations are plotted where nodes are institutions and links are co-authorships, illustrating collaborations between institutions.

# author collaboration network
edu.collab <- biblioNetwork(df,
                            analysis = "collaboration",
                            network = "universities",
                            sep = ";")

# network plot
edu.collabnet = networkPlot(edu.collab,
                            n = 75,
                            Title = "Edu Collaboration", 
                            type = "mds",
                            halo = TRUE,
                            size = 15, 
                            size.cex = T, 
                            edgesize = 1, 
                            labelsize = 0.5, 
                            remove.isolates = TRUE)



# end of code

title: GM: Raw Material
text:
Bifaces from Millsap Cache and Jowell Farm were used to assess morphological stability/variability. Variability in elliptical biface morphology would provide evidence of local differences in morphology as a function of geography and/or raw material. Further, the geographic range/s of local elapid and viper populations differ between sites, thus, if elliptical bifaces are considered morphologically representative, then a difference in morphology should be apparent between the sites.
This analysis follows two recent formal analyses of Perdiz arrow point morphology (Selden Jr et al. 2021; Selden Jr. 2022) and another that is in press (Selden and Dockall, in press), as well as Gahagan biface morphology across the southern Caddo area and central Texas (Selden Jr., Dockall, and Shafer 2018; Selden Jr., Dockall, and Dubied 2020; Selden Jr. 2022), where Perdiz arrow points and Gahagan bifaces have been found to differ in shape across the same geography as Caddo bottles (Selden Jr. 2018a, 2018b, 2019, 2021). Any morphological difference that occurs between Millsap Cache and Jowell Farm would also provide further evidence in support of the shape boundary hypothesis. The analysis also follows another geometric morphometric analysis in which Perdiz arrow points from the ancestral Caddo area were found to differ as a function of time, raw material, and burial context (Selden Jr et al. 2021). While temporal and depositional contexts are unknown for both caches of bifaces used in this study, any finding/s of extant morphological differences would support the hypothesis of elliptical biface morphology as a function of geography and/or raw material.

text:
Generalised Procrustes Analysis
Landmark data were aligned to a global coordinate system (Bookstein et al. 1999; Gunz, Mitteroecker, and Bookstein 2005; Kendall 1981, 1984; Slice 2001), achieved through generalised Procrustes superimposition (Bookstein 1986; Rohlf and Slice 1990; Rohlf 1999) in R using the geomorph and RRPP packages (Adams and Collyer 2015; Collyer and Adams 2018; Adams et al. 2017; Adams and Otarola-Castillo 2013; Baken et al. 2021). Procrustes superimposition translates and rotates the coordinate data to allow for comparisons among objects, while also scaling each biface using unit-centroid size—the square root of the sum of squared distances from each landmark to the specimen’s centroid (Chapman 1990; Dryden and Mardia 1998; Gower 1975; Rohlf and Slice 1990). The geomorph package uses a partial Procrustes superimposition that projects the aligned specimens into tangent space subsequent to alignment in preparation for the use of multivariate methods that assume linear space (Dryden and Mardia 1993; Kent and Mardia 2001; Rohlf 1999; Slice 2001).

title: GM: Raw Material
text:
Procrustes ANOVA: Allometry
To assess whether shape changes with size (allometry), Procrustes ANOVAs (Goodall 1991) were run that enlist effect-sizes (zscores) computed as standard deviates of the generated sampling distributions (Collyer, Sekora, and Adams 2015). A residual randomization permutation procedure (RRPP; n = 10,000 permutations) was used for all Procrustes ANOVAs (Adams and Collyer 2015; Collyer and Adams 2018), which has higher statistical power and a greater ability to identify patterns in the data should they be present (Anderson and Ter Braak 2003).

# allometry
fit.size <- procD.lm(shape ~ size, 
                     data = gdf, 
                     
                     print.progress = FALSE, 
                     iter = 9999)

# shape change with size?
anova(fit.size)

title: Divergent elliptical biface morphology: Distinct local retouch practice or serpent dance proxy for Elapids and Vipers?
text: This process of comparison, of recognising in one form a definite permutation or deformation of another, apart altogether from a precise and adequate understanding of the original “type” or standard of comparison, lies within the immediate province of mathematics, and finds its solution in the elementary use of a certain method of the mathematician (Thompson 1917).

title: Divergent elliptical biface morphology: Distinct local retouch practice or serpent dance proxy for Elapids and Vipers?
text:
Background
Elliptical bifaces are prevalent at Mississippian and Caddo sites throughout the American Southeast, and are depicted in motifs that adorn shell gorgets and bowls, representing two distinct dances. Morphological attributes of elliptical bifaces used in Mississippian and Caddo imagery differ in noteworthy ways that are manifest in the associated material culture assemblages. Those from Caddo sites more readily articulate with the serpent dance, where the decorative motif portrays the emergence of the Hero Twins from the Beneath World; each grasping an elliptical biface.

title: Divergent elliptical biface morphology: Distinct local retouch practice or serpent dance proxy for Elapids and Vipers?
text:
Hypotheses
The elliptical bifaces used in this study come from two of the largest caches found at Caddo sites, and each was manufactured with a distinct raw material, providing for an empirical test of morphological differences as a function of raw material. If the elliptical bifaces were intended to represent local elapid and viper populations in the serpent dance, then their morphology may differ due to regional differences in biogeography. The sample of elliptical bifaces was also divided into two size classes; one conceptually reflective of production (large) or adult elapids and vipers, and the other with local reduction practices (small) or juvenile elapids and vipers.
Size classes were used to assess whether modifications by Caddo knappers may have yielded similar—convergent—biface morphologies in the small size class suggestive of relative standardization due to resharpening and/or retouch in one instance, and morphological divergence associated with adult elapids and vipers in the other. Size classes were also used to test two hypotheses related to morphological diversity; one where greater morphological variation would be apparent in the small size class due to idiosyncratic responses related to local retouch practices, and a second where greater morphological variation would be apparent in the large size class due to differences in constituent elapid and viper communities depicted by the bifaces.

title: Divergent elliptical biface morphology: Distinct local retouch practice or serpent dance proxy for Elapids and Vipers?
text:
Results
Results demonstrate that elliptical biface shape does not differ by raw material, but size does, suggesting that a shared—and morphologically-consistent—mental template was maintained independent of biface size and constituent community differences in elapids and vipers. The subsequent analysis of elliptical biface morphology by size class demonstrated that size does not differ by raw material in the large class, but in the small class, it does. These findings support the argument that elliptical biface morphology diverges through local reduction practices, while simultaneously nullifying the hypothesis that biface shape reflects the morphology of local elapid and viper communities. As expected, greater shape diversity occurs in the small size class, where the Jowell Farm bifaces were found to be more morphologically diverse than those from Millsap Cache. Thus, distinct local reduction practices are advanced as the driver of extant morphological differences expressed in elliptical bifaces.

Keywords
American Southeast, Caddo, NAGPRA, computational archaeology, archaeoinformatics, museum studies, digital humanities, non-Western art history, geometric morphometrics, STEM, STEAM, ovoid biface, Galt biface, Jowell knife, Jowell knives, Jowell biface, Nikolas knife, lithics, parallel-oblique flaking

knitr::include_graphics('./images/map.png')




Location of Millsap Cache, Jowell Farm, and other Caddo sites mentioned in the text. Elliptical bifaces have been found in all but one major drainage basin in the ancestral Caddo area (dashed/white).

title: Divergent elliptical biface morphology: Distinct local retouch practice or serpent dance proxy for Elapids and Vipers?
text:
Hypotheses

Elliptical bifaces found at Millsap Cache were manufactured using Kay County Chert (Millsap and Dickson 1968), while those from Jowell Farm were manufactured using Edwards Chert. Differences in stone tool shape as a function of raw material have been reported for Perdiz arrow points in the region (Selden Jr et al. 2021); however, others have demonstrated that the attribution of morphological variability to raw material differences is an assumption that warrants regular testing, suggesting that primacy should not be assumed (Eren et al. 2014). Thus, a comparison of between-site morphology was included to assess elliptical biface morphology as a function of raw material.


The biogeography of elapid and viper species differs within the ancestral Caddo area, where elapid populations occur south of the Red River, excluding them from the geography surrounding Millsap Cache. If elliptical biface morphology was intended to represent local elapid and viper populations, then elliptical bifaces from these sites will differ due to differences in the constituent communities of elapids and vipers.


The elliptical bifaces from Jowell Farm were discovered in an area of the ancestral Caddo region where others have assumed large bifaces to be products of external manufacture due to the absence of local production evidence and the availability of raw material/s of similar size and quality (Shafer 1973; Selden Jr., Dockall, and Shafer 2018; Selden Jr., Dockall, and Dubied 2020). Given the potential that elliptical bifaces were produced by knappers outside of the ancestral Caddo region for at least one of the caches (Jowell Farm), it is assumed that the smaller elliptical bifaces will more readily reflect morphology imposed by Caddo knappers through resharpening and/or retouch incurred through normal use (Selden Jr. 2022). Thus, it is expected that elliptical bifaces will express convergent morphology, where morphological consistency is achieved through the idiosyncratic approaches to resharpening and/or retouch by Caddo knappers in the small size class.


Elapid and viper species will progress through the smaller size class during normal developmental stages before reaching adulthood, where their morphology differs within and among species. If elliptical biface morphology is thought to represent distinct elapid and viper populations, then the most pronounced morphological difference will occur in the large size class among adults. Thus, if elliptical bifaces were intended to represent elapid and viper species, then the morphological pattern will be identical to H2. However, analytical results would be read in reverse, where expected similarities occur at the smaller size class, before diverging in the large size class.


A measure of morphological disparity was subsequently used to assess whether biface morphology may have been more morphologically diverse in the large size class, suggestive of greater diversity in biface shape or size related to production activities (Selden Jr. 2022). An alternative hypothesis is that the idiosyncratic responses to resharpening and/or retouch by Caddo knappers required to address damage incurred through normal use generate greater morphological diversity in the small size class (Selden Jr. 2022).


Elapid and viper species express greater morphological diversity at their larger size. Thus, if elliptical bifaces were intended to represent elapid and viper species, and biological diversity differs between sites—elapid biogeography restricted to the area of Jowell Farm—then morphological disparity will occur between sites in the large size class.

title: Divergent elliptical biface morphology: Distinct local retouch practice or serpent dance proxy for Elapids and Vipers?
text:
Generalised Procrustes Analysis
Landmark data were aligned to a global coordinate system (Bookstein et al. 1999; Gunz, Mitteroecker, and Bookstein 2005; Kendall 1981, 1984; Slice 2001), achieved through generalised Procrustes superimposition (Bookstein 1986; Rohlf and Slice 1990; Rohlf 1999) in R using the geomorph and RRPP packages (Adams and Collyer 2015; Collyer and Adams 2018; Adams et al. 2017; Adams and Otarola-Castillo 2013; Baken et al. 2021). Procrustes superimposition translates and rotates the coordinate data to allow for comparisons among objects, while also scaling each biface using unit-centroid size—the square root of the sum of squared distances from each landmark to the specimen’s centroid (Chapman 1990; Dryden and Mardia 1998; Gower 1975; Rohlf and Slice 1990). The geomorph package uses a partial Procrustes superimposition that projects the aligned specimens into tangent space subsequent to alignment in preparation for the use of multivariate methods that assume linear space (Dryden and Mardia 1993; Kent and Mardia 2001; Rohlf 1999; Slice 2001).

knitr::include_graphics('./images/gpa.png')




Results of generalised Procrustes analysis for elliptical bifaces from the Millsap Cache and Jowell Farm. Mean consensus configuration shown in black; individual bifaces in gray.

title: Divergent elliptical biface morphology: Distinct local retouch practice or serpent dance proxy for Elapids and Vipers?
text:
Principal Components Analysis
Principal components analysis (Jolliffe 2002) was used to visualise shape variation among the elliptical bifaces, and the scatterplot represents the dispersion of shapes in tangent space (Adams, Rohlf, and Slice 2013; Bookstein 1991; O’Higgins and Jones 1998; Rohlf and Marcus 1993). Shape ranges described by each principal axis are commonly visualized using thin-plate spline warping of a reference image (Klingenberg 2013; Sherratt et al. 2014).

knitr::include_graphics('./images/pca.png')




PCA summarizing shape variation in elliptical bifaces.

title: Divergent elliptical biface morphology: Distinct local retouch practice or serpent dance proxy for Elapids and Vipers?
text:
Procrustes ANOVA
To assess whether shape differs by size (allometry), and whether shape and size differed by raw material and size class, Procrustes ANOVAs (Goodall 1991) were run that enlist effect-sizes (zscores) computed as standard deviates of the generated sampling distributions (Collyer, Sekora, and Adams 2015). A residual randomization permutation procedure (RRPP; n = 10,000 permutations) was used for all Procrustes ANOVAs (Adams and Collyer 2015; Collyer and Adams 2018), which has higher statistical power and a greater ability to identify patterns in the data should they be present (Anderson and Ter Braak 2003).

Morphological disparity
An analysis of morphological disparity was used to identify potential differences in morphological diversity between size classes (Collyer and Adams 2020; Foote 1993; Zelditch et al. 2004).

shapesGM <- readland.shapes(shapes, nCurvePts = c(15, 20, 35))

                  header = TRUE, 
                  row.names = 1)

title: Define Size classes
text:
Generalised Procrustes Analysis
Landmark data were aligned to a global coordinate system (Bookstein et al. 1999; Gunz, Mitteroecker, and Bookstein 2005; Kendall 1981, 1984; Slice 2001), achieved through generalised Procrustes superimposition (Bookstein 1986; Rohlf and Slice 1990; Rohlf 1999) in R using the geomorph and RRPP packages (Adams and Collyer 2015; Collyer and Adams 2018; Adams et al. 2017; Adams and Otarola-Castillo 2013; Baken et al. 2021). Procrustes superimposition translates and rotates the coordinate data to allow for comparisons among objects, while also scaling each biface using unit-centroid size—the square root of the sum of squared distances from each landmark to the specimen’s centroid (Chapman 1990; Dryden and Mardia 1998; Gower 1975; Rohlf and Slice 1990). The geomorph package uses a partial Procrustes superimposition that projects the aligned specimens into tangent space subsequent to alignment in preparation for the use of multivariate methods that assume linear space (Dryden and Mardia 1993; Kent and Mardia 2001; Rohlf 1999; Slice 2001).

# gpa ----
Y.gpa <- gpagen(shapesGM, print.progress = FALSE)

# geomorph data frame ----
gdf <- geomorph.data.frame(shape = Y.gpa$coords, 
                           size = Y.gpa$Csize,
                           site = qdata$site)

# add centroid size to qdata
qdata$csz <- Y.gpa$Csize

title: Define Size classes
text:
Assign size class
Centroid size—the square root of the sum of squared distances of all landmarks from the centroid—is the measure of size used in landmark geometric morphometrics (Manthey and Ousley 2020). The mean centroid size was identified for elliptical bifaces from each site. All bifaces with centroid sizes larger than the mean were assigned to the large class; those with centroid sizes below the mean were assigned to the small class.

#select vars
pre.data <- qdata %>% 
  select(site:csz)

# millsap subset----
millsap <- filter(pre.data,
                  site == "Millsap Cache")

# calculate mean centroid size
mean.csz <- mean(millsap$csz)

# assign L/S varieties based on mean centroid size
lcheck2 <- millsap$csz >= mean.csz
lcheck3 <- millsap$csz >= 0 & millsap$csz < mean.csz

millsap$size <- ""
millsap$size <- ifelse(lcheck2, "L", millsap$size)
millsap$size <- ifelse(lcheck3, "S", millsap$size)

# an13 subset----
an13 <- subset(pre.data,
               site == "Jowell Farm")

# calculate the mean length
mean.csz <- mean(an13$csz)

# assign L/S varieties based on mean length
lcheck2 <- an13$csz >= mean.csz
lcheck3 <- an13$csz >= 0 & an13$csz < mean.csz

an13$size <- ""
an13$size <- ifelse(lcheck2, "L", an13$size)
an13$size <- ifelse(lcheck3, "S", an13$size)

# aggregate data
mx <- bind_rows(millsap, an13)

# join site and size class
qdata2 <- mx %>% 
  unite("merged", site, size, remove = FALSE) %>% 
  select(c('merged', 'site', 'size'))

# output csv for use in gm analysis
write.csv(qdata2, "qdata.merged.csv")
